name: solomon
title: Solomon
description: An a­bridg­ment of the proverbs at­trib­ut­ed to Solomon

verses.translation: My son, donʼt for­get my teach­ing, but let your heart keep my commandments,
for they will bring you man­y days, years of life, and peace.
Donʼt let kind­ness and truth leave you. Tie them a­round your neck. Write them on the tab­let of your heart.
Then you will find fa­vor and high re­gard in the sight of God and man.
Trust in Gᴏᴅ with all your heart, and donʼt lean on your own un­der­stand­ing.
In all your ways ac­knowl­edge him, and he will make your paths straight.
Donʼt be wise in your own eyes. Fear Gᴏᴅ, and turn a­way from evil.
It will be heal­ing to your bod­y, and re­fresh­ment to your bones.
Hon­or Gᴏᴅ with your wealth, and with the first­fruits of all your pro­duce,
then your barns will be filled with plen­ty, and your vats will o­ver­flow with new wine.
My son, donʼt re­ject the dis­ci­pline of Gᴏᴅ or loathe his re­proof;
for Gᴏᴅ reproves the one he loves, just as a fa­ther reproves the son in whom he delights.
Hap­py is the man who finds wis­dom, and the man who gains un­der­stand­ing.
For she is more prof­it­a­ble than sil­ver, and her gain is bet­ter than fi­ne gold.
She is more pre­cious than jewels, and noth­ing you de­sire compares with her.
Long life is in her right hand. In her left hand are rich­es and hon­or.
Her ways are pleas­ant, and all her paths are peace­ful.
She is a tree of life to those who take hold of her. Those who hold her fast are hap­py.
Gᴏᴅ founded the earth by wis­dom. He established the heavens by un­der­stand­ing.
By his knowl­edge the depths broke o­pen, and the clouds drip with dew.
My son, donʼt lose sight of them. Keep sound wis­dom and dis­cre­tion.
They will be life for your soul, and a­dorn­ment for your neck.
Then you will walk on your way se­cure­ly, and your foot wonʼt stum­ble.
When you lie down, you wonʼt be a­fraid. When you lie down, your sleep will be sweet.
Donʼt fear sud­den dis­as­ter or the ru­in of the wick­ed when it co­mes,
for Gᴏᴅ will be your con­fi­dence, and will keep your foot from be­ing caught.
Donʼt with­hold good from those who de­serve it, when it is in your pow­er to do it.
Donʼt say to your neigh­bor, “Go, and come back. Iʼll give it to­mor­row,” when you have it with you.
Donʼt plan evil a­gainst your neigh­bor, who lives trustingly be­side you.
Donʼt con­tend with a man with­out cause, when he has done you no harm.
Donʼt en­vy a vi­o­lent man or choose any of his ways,
for the de­vi­ous are an a­bom­i­na­tion to Gᴏᴅ, but he is a friend to the up­right.
The curse of Gᴏᴅ is on the house of the wick­ed, but he blesses the dwell­ing of the right­eous.
He mocks the mock­ers, but shows fa­vor to the hum­ble.
The wise will in­her­it hon­or, but fools get shame.
Lis­ten, sons, to a fatherʼs in­struc­tion, and pay at­ten­tion so that you may gain un­der­stand­ing.
For I give you sound in­struc­tion. Donʼt a­ban­don my teach­ing.
When I was a son to my fa­ther, ten­der and the on­ly son in my motherʼs sight,
he taught me, and said to me: “Let your heart hold on to my words. Keep my commandments and live.
Get wis­dom. Get un­der­stand­ing. Donʼt for­get or turn a­way from the words of my mouth.
Donʼt for­sake her, and she will guard you. Love her, and she will watch o­ver you.
The be­gin­ning of wis­dom is this: Get wis­dom, and what­ev­er else you get, get un­der­stand­ing.
Prize her, and she will ex­alt you. If you em­brace her, she will hon­or you.
She will place on your head a gar­land of grace. She will pres­ent you with a crown of beau­ty.”
Lis­ten, my son, and ac­cept my sayings, and the years of your life will be man­y.
I have taught you in the way of wis­dom. I have led you in up­right paths.
When you walk, your steps wonʼt be hindered. When you run, you wonʼt stum­ble.
Hold on to in­struc­tion. Donʼt let go. Guard her, for she is your life.
Donʼt en­ter the path of the wick­ed, and donʼt walk in the way of evil men.
A­void it. Donʼt trav­el on it. Turn a­way from it, and pass on.
For they can­not sleep un­less they do evil. They are robbed of sleep un­less they make some­one stum­ble.
For they eat the bread of wick­ed­ness, and drink the wine of vi­o­lence.
But the path of the right­eous is like the light of dawn, which shines brighter and brighter un­til mid­day.
The way of the wick­ed is like dark­ness. They donʼt know what makes them stum­ble.
My son, pay at­ten­tion to my words. Lis­ten care­ful­ly to my sayings.
Donʼt lose sight of them. Keep them with­in your heart.
For they are life to those who find them, and health to their whole bod­y.
Watch o­ver your heart with all dil­i­gence, for the springs of life flow from it.
Put a­way from you de­ceit­ful speech, and put de­vi­ous talk far from you.
Let your eyes look di­rect­ly a­head and your gaze straight in front of you.
Care­ful­ly con­sid­er the path of your feet, then all your ways will be sure.
Donʼt turn to the right or to the left. Keep your foot from evil.
My son, pay at­ten­tion to my wis­dom. Lis­ten care­ful­ly to my un­der­stand­ing,
that you may main­tain dis­cre­tion, and that your lips may guard knowl­edge.
The lips of a for­bid­den wom­an drip hon­ey, and her speech is smooth­er than oil,
but in the end sheʼs as bit­ter as worm­wood, and as sharp as a double-edged sword.
Her feet go down to death. Her steps lead straight to hell.
She does­nʼt pon­der the path of life. Her ways are un­sta­ble, and she does­nʼt know it.
Now then, my sons, lis­ten to me, and donʼt de­part from the words of my mouth.
Keep your way far from her. Donʼt go near the door of her house
lest you give your vig­or to others and your years to some­one cru­el,
lest strangers feast on your wealth, your labors en­rich the house of a for­eign­er,
and at the end of your life you groan when your flesh and bod­y are con­sumed.
You will say, “How I hat­ed dis­ci­pline! How my heart de­spised re­proof!
I did­nʼt o­bey my teachers or lis­ten to my instructors!
I am al­most in ut­ter ru­in in the midst of the as­sem­bly and con­gre­ga­tion.”
Drink wa­ter from your own cis­tern, and fresh wa­ter from your own well.
Should your springs be scattered a­broad, streams of wa­ter in the streets?
Let them be yours a­lone, and not for strangers with you.
Let your foun­tain be bless­ed, and re­joice in the wife of your youth,
as a lov­ing deer and a grace­ful doe. Let her breasts sat­is­fy you al­ways, and be ex­hil­a­rat­ed al­ways with her love.
Why, my son, should you be ex­hil­a­rat­ed with a for­bid­den wom­an, or em­brace the bos­om of a strang­er?
For a manʼs ways are be­fore the eyes of Gᴏᴅ, and he considers all his paths.
The iniquities of the wick­ed en­trap him. He is held in the cords of his sin.
He dies for lack of dis­ci­pline, and be­cause of his great fol­ly he will go a­stray.
My son, if you have put up se­cu­ri­ty for your neigh­bor or have giv­en a pledge for a strang­er,
if you have been snared or caught with the words of your mouth,
then do this, my son, and free your­self. You have fall­en in­to your neighborʼs hands. Go, hum­ble your­self, and plead with your neigh­bor.
Give your eyes no sleep and your eyelids no slum­ber.
Save your­self like a ga­zelle from the hunterʼs hand, and like a bird from the fowlerʼs hand.
Go to the ant, you i­dler. Ob­serve its ways, and be wise.
With­out chief, of­fic­er, or rul­er,
it prepares its provisions in sum­mer, and gathers its food dur­ing har­vest.
How long will you lie down, you i­dler? When will you get up from your sleep?
A lit­tle sleep, a lit­tle slum­ber, a lit­tle folding of the hands to rest,
and pov­er­ty will come up­on you like a rob­ber, and want like an armed man.
A worth­less per­son, a wick­ed man, goes a­round speak­ing per­verse­ly.
With per­ver­si­ty in his heart, he devises evil con­tin­u­al­ly, and sows dis­cord.
There­fore ca­lam­i­ty will strike him sud­den­ly. In­stant­ly he will be bro­ken be­yond heal­ing.
Sev­en things are an a­bom­i­na­tion to Gᴏᴅ:
haugh­ty eyes, a ly­ing tongue, hands that shed in­no­cent blood,
a heart that devises wick­ed plans, feet that run swift­ly to evil,
a false wit­ness who utters lies, and one who sows dis­cord a­mong brothers.
My son, keep your fatherʼs com­mand, and donʼt for­sake your motherʼs teach­ing.
Al­ways bind them on your heart. Tie them a­round your neck.
When you walk, they will guide you. When you sleep, they will watch o­ver you. When you wake up, they will talk to you.
For this com­mand is a lamp, this teach­ing is a light, and cor­rec­tive dis­ci­pline is the way to life,
keep­ing you from the evil wom­an, from the flattering tongue of an a­dul­ter­ess.
Donʼt de­sire her beau­ty in your heart or let her cap­ti­vate you with her eyes.
For a prostituteʼs fee is on­ly a loaf of bread, but a mar­ried wom­an hunts down a pre­cious life.
Can a man em­brace fire with­out burn­ing his clothes?
Or can he walk on hot coals with­out scorching his feet?
So is he who goes in to his neighborʼs wife. None who touches her will go un­pun­ished.
Peo­ple donʼt de­spise a thief if he steals to sat­is­fy his hun­ger,
but if caught, he must re­pay sev­en­fold. He will give eve­ry­thing in his house.
He who commits a­dul­ter­y lacks sense, and destroys him­self.
He will get wounds and dis­hon­or, and his dis­grace wonʼt be e­rased.
For jeal­ous­y enrages a hus­band, and he will show no mer­cy in the day of venge­ance.
He wonʼt ac­cept com­pen­sa­tion. He will re­fuse, though you give man­y gifts.
A wom­an met him, dressed as a pros­ti­tute, and cun­ning of heart.
She seizes him, kisses him, and bra­zen­ly says to him,
“I had to of­fer peace offerings. To­day Iʼve paid my vows.
Iʼve spread my couch with coverings, with col­ored linens from Egypt.
Come, letʼs drink our fill of love un­til morn­ing. Letʼs de­light our­selves with caresses.”
She seduces him with her per­sua­sive speech. With her flattering lips she lures him.
He follows her at once, like an ox go­ing to the slaugh­ter, like a deer step­ping in­to a trap.
Donʼt let your heart turn a­side to her ways. Donʼt stray in­to her paths.
For she has cast down man­y victims, and all her slain are nu­mer­ous.
He who troubles his own house will in­her­it the wind.
An ex­cel­lent wife is her husbandʼs crown, but she who brings shame is like rottenness in his bones.
He who walks with wise men will be­come wise, but the com­pan­ion of fools will suf­fer harm.
He who spares the rod hates his son, but he who loves him disciplines him dil­i­gent­ly.
Leave the pres­ence of a fool, for you wonʼt find knowl­edge in his speech.
A large pop­u­la­tion is a kingʼs glo­ry, but with­out peo­ple a prince is ruined.
Bet­ter is a serv­ing of vegetables where there is love, than a fattened ox served with ha­tred.
When a manʼs ways please Gᴏᴅ, he makes e­ven his enemies to be at peace with him.
Grand­chil­dren are the crown of old men, and fathers are the glo­ry of their sons.
He who conceals an of­fense seeks love, but he who repeats a mat­ter sep­a­rates close friends.
Let a man meet a bear robbed of her cubs, rath­er than a fool in his fol­ly.
He who sires a fool does so to his own sor­row, and the fa­ther of a fool has no joy.
A fool­ish son is a grief to his fa­ther, and bit­ter­ness to her who bore him.
He who isolates him­self seeks his own de­sire, and rebels a­gainst all sound wis­dom.
He who finds a wife finds a good thing, and obtains fa­vor from Gᴏᴅ.
He who has man­y friends co­mes to ru­in, but there is a friend who stays clos­er than a broth­er.
A house and wealth are in­her­it­ed from fathers, but a pru­dent wife is from Gᴏᴅ.
A kingʼs ter­ror is like the lionʼs roar; he who provokes him to an­ger forfeits his own life.
A gos­sip reveals secrets, there­fore donʼt as­so­ci­ate with him who talks too much.
Train up a child in the way he should go; e­ven when he is old he wonʼt de­part from it.
Sel­dom set foot in your neighborʼs house, lest he grow wea­ry of you, and hate you.
He who loves wis­dom brings joy to his fa­ther, but a com­pan­ion of prostitutes wastes his wealth.
Does­nʼt wis­dom call, and un­der­stand­ing raise her voice?
“To you, O men, I call, and my voice is to the sons of men.
O na­ive ones, learn pru­dence. O fools, learn sense.
Take my in­struc­tion in­stead of sil­ver, and knowl­edge rath­er than choice gold.
For wis­dom is bet­ter than jewels, and all de­sir­a­ble things can­not com­pare to it.
Gᴏᴅ pos­sessed me at the be­gin­ning of his way, be­fore his works of old.
When he established the heavens, I was there.
Now, my sons, lis­ten to me, for bless­ed are those who keep my ways.
Lis­ten to in­struc­tion and be wise. Donʼt ne­glect it.
For he who finds me finds life, and will ob­tain fa­vor of Gᴏᴅ.”
Donʼt re­prove a scoff­er, or he will hate you. Re­prove a wise man, and he will love you.
In­struct a wise man, and he will be wis­er still. Teach a right­eous man, and he will in­crease in learn­ing.
The fear of Gᴏᴅ is the be­gin­ning of wis­dom.
He who heeds in­struc­tion is on the path of life, but he who ignores re­proof goes a­stray.
The foolʼs way is right in his own eyes, but a wise man listens to coun­sel.
The teach­ing of the wise is a foun­tain of life, turn­ing one a­way from the snares of death.
Pov­er­ty and shame will come to him who ignores in­struc­tion, but he who heeds re­proof will be honored.
A re­buke goes deeper in­to one who has un­der­stand­ing than a hun­dred lashes in­to a fool.
Cease listening to in­struc­tion, my son, and you will stray from the words of knowl­edge.
A wise son makes a fa­ther glad, but a fool­ish son brings grief to his moth­er.
Do­ing wick­ed­ness is like sport to a fool, but wis­dom is pleas­ure to a man of un­der­stand­ing.
The fool will be serv­ant to the wise of heart.
A foolʼs dis­pleas­ure is known at once, but a pru­dent man ignores an in­sult.
The na­ive believes eve­ry­thing, but the pru­dent considers his steps.
A wise man is cau­tious and turns a­way from evil, but a fool is reck­less and care­less.
A pru­dent serv­ant will rule o­ver a shame­ful son, and will share the in­her­it­ance a­mong the brothers.
The pru­dent sees dan­ger and hides him­self, but the na­ive go on and suf­fer for it.
Ill-gotten gains do not prof­it, but right­eous­ness delivers from death.
Gᴏᴅ will not let the right­eous go hun­gry, but he thwarts the crav­ing of the wick­ed.
The mem­o­ry of the right­eous is a bless­ing, but the name of the wick­ed will rot.
The tongue of the right­eous is like choice sil­ver; the heart of the wick­ed is of lit­tle worth.
The lips of the right­eous feed man­y, but fools die for lack of sense.
The fear of Gᴏᴅ prolongs life, but the years of the wick­ed will be shortened.
The right­eous­ness of the blame­less will di­rect his way, but the wick­ed will fall by his own wick­ed­ness.
The right­eous­ness of the up­right will res­cue them, but the treach­er­ous will be trapped by their own desires.
The right­eous is delivered from trou­ble, but the wick­ed takes his place.
The wick­ed earns de­cep­tive wages, but he who sows right­eous­ness gets a sure re­ward.
The de­sire of the right­eous turns out well, but the ex­pec­ta­tion of the wick­ed is wrath.
If the right­eous will be rewarded on earth, how much more the wick­ed and the sin­ner.
A man will not be established by wick­ed­ness, but the root of the right­eous will not be moved.
The wick­ed are overthrown and are no more, but the house of the right­eous will stand.
The right­eous is a guide to his neigh­bor, but the way of the wick­ed leads them a­stray.
Dis­as­ter pursues sinners, but the right­eous will be rewarded with good.
The right­eous has e­nough to sat­is­fy his ap­pe­tite, but the stom­ach of the wick­ed is emp­ty.
The evil bow down be­fore the good, and the wick­ed at the gates of the right­eous.
Wonʼt they who de­vise evil go a­stray? But those who de­vise good will find kind­ness and truth.
Right­eous­ness exalts a na­tion, but sin is a dis­grace to any peo­ple.
The sac­ri­fice of the wick­ed is an a­bom­i­na­tion to Gᴏᴅ, but the pray­er of the up­right is his de­light.
When jus­tice is done, it is a joy to the right­eous, but a ter­ror to evildoers.
The wick­ed flee when no one pursues, but the right­eous are as bold as a li­on.
A slack hand causes pov­er­ty, but a dil­i­gent hand makes rich.
A son who gathers in the sum­mer is pru­dent, but one who sleeps dur­ing har­vest is shame­ful.
Like vin­e­gar to the teeth and smoke to the eyes, so is the i­dler to those who send him.
The hand of the dil­i­gent will rule, but the sloth­ful will be put to forced la­bor.
The i­dler craves, yet gets noth­ing, but the dil­i­gent is ful­ly sat­is­fied.
There is prof­it in all la­bor, but mer­e talk leads on­ly to pov­er­ty.
A workerʼs ap­pe­tite works for him, for his hun­ger urges him on.
Who­ev­er is slack in his work is broth­er to him who destroys.
La­zi­ness brings on deep sleep, and an i­dle man will suf­fer hun­ger.
The i­dler bur­ies his hand in the dish, but will not e­ven bring it back to his mouth.
The i­dler does­nʼt plow in sea­son, so he looks dur­ing har­vest, and has noth­ing.
Donʼt love sleep, lest you come to pov­er­ty. O­pen your eyes, and you will have plen­ty of food.
The i­dler says, “Thereʼs a li­on out­side. Iʼll be killed in the streets.”
As a door turns on its hinges, so does the i­dler on his bed.
The i­dler is wis­er in his own eyes than sev­en men who can an­swer sen­si­bly.
Know well the con­di­tion of your flocks, and pay at­ten­tion to your herds;
for rich­es arenʼt for­ev­er and a crown does­nʼt en­dure to all generations.
He who works his land will have plen­ty of food, but he who follows worth­less pursuits will have plen­ty of pov­er­ty.
He who walks in in­teg­ri­ty walks se­cure­ly, but he who perverts his ways will be found out.
The in­teg­ri­ty of the up­right will guide them, but the per­ver­si­ty of the treach­er­ous will de­stroy them.
A right­eous man who walks in his in­teg­ri­ty; bless­ed are his chil­dren af­ter him.
To do right­eous­ness and jus­tice is more ac­cept­a­ble to Gᴏᴅ than sac­ri­fice.
The sac­ri­fice of the wick­ed is an a­bom­i­na­tion; how much more when he brings it with evil in­tent.
Bet­ter is the poor who walks in his in­teg­ri­ty, than the rich who is crook­ed in his ways.
He who walks in in­teg­ri­ty will be delivered, but he who is crook­ed will sud­den­ly fall.
Ha­tred stirs up con­flict, but love co­vers all offenses.
A hot-tempered man stirs up con­flict, but the slow to an­ger calms con­ten­tion.
Starting a con­flict is like re­leas­ing a flood, so a­ban­don the dis­pute be­fore it breaks out.
Cast­ing the lot ends quarrels, and decides be­tween pow­er­ful opponents.
An offended broth­er is harder to win than a strong cit­y, and contentions are like the bars of a cas­tle.
Stay­ing a­way from strife is an hon­or for a man, but any fool will quar­rel.
Itʼs bet­ter to live in a cor­ner of the roof than in a house shared with a con­ten­tious wom­an.
Itʼs bet­ter to live in a des­ert than with a con­ten­tious and complaining wom­an.
Drive out the mocker, and con­ten­tion will de­part, and quarrels and dis­hon­or will cease.
With­out wood the fire goes out, and with­out a gos­sip con­ten­tion dies down.
Like char­coal to hot embers and wood to fire, so is a con­ten­tious man for kin­dling strife.
Wis­dom is found on the lips of the dis­cern­ing, but a rod is for the back of him who lacks sense.
Eve­ry pru­dent man works with knowl­edge, but a fool flaunts his fol­ly.
There is a way that seems right to a man, but its end is the way to death.
How much bet­ter to get wis­dom than gold. To get un­der­stand­ing is pref­er­a­ble to sil­ver.
He who answers be­fore he listens: it is fol­ly and shame to him.
The mind of the pru­dent acquires knowl­edge, and the ear of the wise seeks knowl­edge.
En­thu­si­asm with­out knowl­edge is not good, and has­ty feet go a­stray.
Lis­ten to coun­sel and re­ceive in­struc­tion so that you may be wise the rest of your days.
He who conceals ha­tred has ly­ing lips, and he who spreads slan­der is a fool.
When there are man­y words, trans­gres­sion is un­a­void­a­ble, but he who restrains his lips is wise.
He who belittles his neigh­bor lacks sense, but a man of un­der­stand­ing re­mains si­lent.
A gos­sip goes a­bout revealing secrets, but he who is trust­wor­thy conceals a mat­ter.
A beau­ti­ful wom­an with­out dis­cre­tion is like a gold ring in a pigʼs snout.
An evil man is en­snared by the trans­gres­sion of his lips, but the right­eous will es­cape from trou­ble.
There is one who speaks rash­ly like thrusts of a sword, but the tongue of the wise brings heal­ing.
A pru­dent man conceals knowl­edge, but a foolʼs heart proclaims fol­ly.
He who guards his mouth preserves his life, but he who opens wide his lips co­mes to ru­in.
In the foolʼs mouth is a rod for his back, but the lips of the wise will pro­tect them.
A gen­tle an­swer turns a­way wrath, but a harsh word stirs up an­ger.
A sooth­ing tongue is a tree of life, but a per­verse tongue breaks the spir­it.
A man finds joy in giv­ing an apt an­swer; and a time­ly word, how good it is!
The heart of the right­eous ponders how to an­swer, but the mouth of the wick­ed blurts out evil things.
Pleas­ant words are a hon­ey­comb: sweet to the soul, and health to the bod­y.
A per­verse man spreads strife, and a gos­sip sep­a­rates close friends.
He who restrains his words has knowl­edge, and he who has a cool spir­it is a man of un­der­stand­ing.
E­ven a fool is con­sid­ered wise when he keeps si­lent. When he closes his lips, he is con­sid­ered pru­dent.
A fool does not de­light in un­der­stand­ing, but on­ly in air­ing his o­pin­ion.
His lips bring strife, and his mouth invites a beat­ing.
His mouth is his ru­in, and his lips are the snare of his soul.
There is gold, and an a­bun­dance of jewels, but lips of knowl­edge are a rare treas­ure.
He who guards his mouth and tongue keeps him­self out of trou­ble.
He who loves pu­ri­ty of heart, and speaks gra­cious­ly will have the king as a friend.
Like a mad­man who throws firebrands, ar­rows, and death,
is the man who deceives his neigh­bor, and says, “I was on­ly jok­ing!”
He who blesses his neigh­bor with a loud voice ear­ly in the morn­ing will be counted as curs­ing.
Do you see a man who is has­ty in his words? There is more hope for a fool than for him.
Dis­hon­est scales are an a­bom­i­na­tion to Gᴏᴅ, but an ac­cu­rate weight is his de­light.
Ly­ing lips are an a­bom­i­na­tion to Gᴏᴅ, but those who act faith­ful­ly are his de­light.
A just bal­ance and scales be­long to Gᴏᴅ, all the weights in the bag are his con­cern.
Ac­quit­ting the guilt­y, and condemning the right­eous are both a­like an a­bom­i­na­tion to Gᴏᴅ.
A wick­ed man takes a bribe in se­cret to per­vert the ways of jus­tice.
Be­ing par­tial to the wick­ed is not good, nei­ther is de­priv­ing the right­eous of jus­tice.
A false wit­ness will not go un­pun­ished, and he who speaks lies will not es­cape.
Bread gained by de­ceit is sweet to a man, but af­ter­ward his mouth will be full of grav­el.
Differing weights are an a­bom­i­na­tion to Gᴏᴅ, and a false scale is not good.
When pride co­mes, then co­mes dis­grace, but with the hum­ble is wis­dom.
Bet­ter is he who is light­ly esteemed, and has a serv­ant, than he that hon­ors him­self, and lacks bread.
Gᴏᴅ will tear down the house of the proud, but will pro­tect the borders of the wid­ow.
Eve­ry­one who is proud in heart is an a­bom­i­na­tion to Gᴏᴅ; be as­sured, he will not go un­pun­ished.
Pride co­mes be­fore de­struc­tion, and an ar­ro­gant spir­it be­fore a fall.
It is bet­ter to be hum­ble in spir­it a­mong the low­ly, than to di­vide the spoil with the proud.
Be­fore de­struc­tion a manʼs heart is haugh­ty, but hu­mil­i­ty co­mes be­fore hon­or.
No wis­dom, no un­der­stand­ing, and no coun­sel will pre­vail a­gainst Gᴏᴅ.
The re­ward for hu­mil­i­ty and fear of Gᴏᴅ is rich­es, hon­or, and life.
Do you see a man wise in his own eyes? There is more hope for a fool than for him.
Donʼt boast a­bout to­mor­row, for you donʼt know what a day may bring.
Let an­oth­er praise you, and not your own mouth; a strang­er, and not your own lips.
A manʼs pride will bring him low, but a hum­ble spir­it will ob­tain hon­or.
With­out guid­ance the peo­ple fall, but with man­y counselors there is safe­ty.
The fear of Gᴏᴅ is a foun­tain of life, turn­ing one a­way from the snares of death.
With­out coun­sel plans fail, but with man­y advisers they suc­ceed.
The lot is cast in­to the lap, but its eve­ry de­ci­sion is from Gᴏᴅ.
Es­tab­lish plans by coun­sel, and make war with wise guid­ance.
He who is guar­an­tor for a strang­er will sure­ly suf­fer for it, but he who hates such agreements is se­cure.
He who trusts in his rich­es will fall, but the right­eous will flour­ish like a green leaf.
There is one who pretends to be rich, yet has noth­ing. An­oth­er pretends to be poor, yet has great wealth.
Wealth obtained by fraud will dwin­dle, but he who gathers by la­bor will in­crease it.
A good man leaves an in­her­it­ance to his childrenʼs chil­dren, but the sinnerʼs wealth is stored up for the right­eous.
Where there are no ox­en, the man­ger is clean, but a­bun­dant har­vest co­mes through an oxʼs strength.
The poor is hat­ed e­ven by his neigh­bor, but there are man­y who love the rich.
There is great wealth in the house of the right­eous, but trou­ble accompanies the in­come of the wick­ed.
He who profits il­lic­it­ly troubles his own house, but he who hates bribes will live.
Bet­ter a lit­tle with right­eous­ness than great in­come with in­jus­tice.
Wealth attracts man­y friends, but a poor man is sep­a­rat­ed from his friend.
Man­y seek a gen­er­ous manʼs fa­vor, and eve­ry­one is a friend to him who gives gifts.
All a poor manʼs brothers hate him. How much more do his friends a­void him! He pursues them with words, but they are gone.
The plans of the dil­i­gent lead sure­ly to a­bun­dance, but eve­ry­one who is has­ty co­mes sure­ly to pov­er­ty.
Ac­quir­ing treasures by a ly­ing tongue is a fleet­ing va­por and the pur­suit of death.
He who loves pleas­ure will be­come poor. He who loves wine and oil will not get rich.
There is pre­cious treas­ure and oil in a wise manʼs dwell­ing, but a fool consumes them.
A good name is to be cho­sen o­ver great rich­es, and fa­vor o­ver sil­ver and gold.
The rich and the poor have this in com­mon: Gᴏᴅ is the mak­er of them all.
The rich rules o­ver the poor, and the bor­row­er is a slave to the lend­er.
Like an arch­er who wounds eve­ry­one, so is he who hires a fool or who hires those pass­ing by.
A stin­gy man hastens af­ter wealth, and does­nʼt know that pov­er­ty will come up­on him.
A kind man benefits him­self, but a cru­el man harms him­self.
A right­eous man has re­gard for the life of his an­i­mal, but e­ven the mer­cy of the wick­ed is cru­el.
He who despises his neigh­bor sins, but he who shows kind­ness to the poor is hap­py.
He who oppresses the poor insults his mak­er, but he who is kind to the needy hon­ors him.
If any­one returns evil for good, evil will nev­er leave his house.
He who pursues right­eous­ness and kind­ness will find life, right­eous­ness, and hon­or.
He who digs a pit will fall in­to it, and he who rolls a stone, it will come back on him.
One gives free­ly, yet increases all the more, and an­oth­er withholds what is due, but co­mes on­ly to pov­er­ty.
The gen­er­ous man will pros­per, and he who waters will al­so be watered him­self.
The peo­ple will curse him who withholds grain, but a bless­ing is on the head of him who sells it.
Kind­ness to the poor is a loan to Gᴏᴅ, and he will re­pay his good deed.
It is a snare to say rash­ly, “It is ho­ly,” and on­ly make in­quir­y af­ter the vows.
He who shuts his ear to the cry of the poor will al­so call out and not be answered.
He who is gen­er­ous will be bless­ed, for he shares his bread with the poor.
He who oppresses the poor to in­crease his wealth, or who gives to the rich, will on­ly come to pov­er­ty.
If your en­e­my is hun­gry, give him bread to eat, and if he is thirst­y, give him wa­ter to drink.
He who is full loathes hon­ey, but to the hun­gry any bit­ter thing is sweet.
He who gives to the poor will nev­er want, but he who hides his eyes will have man­y curs­es.
Anx­i­e­ty in a manʼs heart weighs it down, but a good word makes it glad.
Hope de­ferred makes the heart sick, but de­sire ful­filled is a tree of life.
E­ven in laugh­ter the heart may ache, and joy may end in grief.
A man of quick tem­per acts fool­ish­ly, and a man of evil schemes is hat­ed.
He who is slow to an­ger has great un­der­stand­ing, but he who has a quick tem­per promotes fol­ly.
A tran­quil heart is life to the bod­y, but en­vy makes the bones rot.
A glad heart makes a cheer­ful coun­te­nance, but a sorrowful heart breaks the spir­it.
All the days of the afflicted are bad, but a cheer­ful heart has a con­tin­u­al feast.
A kingʼs wrath is a mes­sen­ger of death, but a wise man appeases it.
He who is slow to an­ger is bet­ter than the might­y, and he who rules his spir­it, than he who captures a cit­y.
Who­ev­er mocks the poor insults his mak­er, and he who rejoices at ca­lam­i­ty will not go un­pun­ished.
A joy­ful heart is good med­i­cine, but a bro­ken spir­it dries up the bones.
A manʼs spir­it can en­dure sick­ness, but who can bear a bro­ken spir­it?
A manʼs fool­ish­ness ruins his way, yet his heart rages a­gainst Gᴏᴅ.
Good sense makes a man slow to an­ger, and it is his glo­ry to o­ver­look an of­fense.
A man of great an­ger will pay the pen­al­ty, for if you res­cue him, you will have to do it a­gain.
Wine is a mocker, strong drink a brawl­er, and who­ev­er is led a­stray by them is not wise.
Donʼt say, “I will re­pay evil”. Wait for Gᴏᴅ, and he will save you.
A fool gives full vent to his an­ger, but a wise man holds it back.
